content.webTitle: £100m takes Fulham to top of league - of debtors

fields.headline: £100m takes Fulham to top of league - of debtors
fields.bodyText: Fulham football club has propelled itself up the league table of Premiership indebtedness, with net liabilities topping £100 million for the first time. The west London club, which were at home to Charlton Athletic at Loftus Road yesterday, saw total debts rise from £86m to £107m last season, according to accounts filed at Companies House. The figure beats Manchester City's £60m liabilities, and even stricken Leeds United's £80m mountain of debt. Fulham, though, may not be set to suffer too badly. It has a rich benefactor in chairman Mohamed Fayed and, while it is planning to return to its Craven Cottage stadium next season, Fulham still hopes to realise £35m from the eventual sale of the club's ground. Pre-tax losses last season fell from £34m to £21m. The club has since sold star striker Louis Saha to Manchester United for £12m.
